title: How to Make Iced Green Tea

steps.title: Boil 4 cups (950 milliliters) of water in a large pot.
steps.content: Boil 4 cups (950 milliliters) of water in a large pot. If you would like to make a single serving, boil 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water in a kettle instead and pour it into a mug.

steps.title: Take the pot off the stove, and add 4 to 6 tea bags into the water.
steps.content: Take the pot off the stove, and add 4 to 6 tea bags into the water. The more tea bags you use, the stronger your tea will become. If you would like to make a single serving, dip 1 tea bag into your mug.

steps.title: Let the tea steep for 3 minutes.
steps.content: Let the tea steep for 3 minutes. Avoid steeping it for any longer, or the tea will turn bitter. [5] X Research source Dina Garcia, RD, LDN, CLT. Dietician/Nutritionist. If you'd like a stronger tea, simply use more tea bags.

steps.title: Take the tea bags out of the water.
steps.content: Take the tea bags out of the water. If you'd like, you can bob them up and down before taking them out to release any extra green tea goodness. Be sure to squeeze out any excess water from the bags before discarding them.

steps.title: Let the tea reach room temperature before you place it into the fridge.
steps.content: Let the tea reach room temperature before you place it into the fridge. It may take up to an hour, depending on how warm or cold it is where you live. [5] X Research source Don't put hot tea into the fridge; wait until it cools down a little first. If you put hot tea into the fridge, it may cause the surrounding food to go bad.

steps.title: Leave the tea in the fridge until it becomes cold.
steps.content: Leave the tea in the fridge until it becomes cold. This will take 1 to 2 hours. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Fill 4 tall glasses with ice.
steps.content: Fill 4 tall glasses with ice. How much ice you add is up to you, just make sure that you leave enough room for the tea. If you are making a single serving, fill just one tall glass with ice.

steps.title: Pour the chilled tea into the glasses, and stir in some honey, if desired.
steps.content: Pour the chilled tea into the glasses, and stir in some honey, if desired. If you'd like to save some tea for later, pour it into a large mason jar or a pitcher, and put it into the fridge. The tea will last 3 to 5 days. [7] X Research source Try adding a sprig of mint to your glass of green tea for a refreshing twist! [9] X Research source Dina Garcia, RD, LDN, CLT. Dietician/Nutritionist.

steps.title: Fill a tall glass with 1 cup (240 milliliters) of cold or room temperature water.
steps.content: Fill a tall glass with 1 cup (240 milliliters) of cold or room temperature water. Brewing tea in hot water brings out the bitter flavors of tea. Brewing tea in cold or room temperature water does not do that. Instead, it gives you a smoother taste. [9] X Research source If you'd more servings, switch to a pitcher and add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water for serving you want to make.

steps.title: Add 1 green tea bag, or the equivalent of loose-leaf tea.
steps.content: Add 1 green tea bag, or the equivalent of loose-leaf tea. Some people find that snipping the tea bag open and pouring the leaves directly into the cup results in a better flavor. [10] X Research source If you'd more servings, and add 1 tea bag per serving into the pitcher. A tea bag is equal to 1 tablespoon (2 to 3 grams) of loose-leaf tea.

steps.title: Cover the cup or pitcher, and put it into the refrigerator for 4 to 6 hours.
steps.content: Cover the cup or pitcher, and put it into the refrigerator for 4 to 6 hours. This will give the tea enough time to brew and infuse the water with its delicate flavor. If you like a stronger brew, leave it in the fridge for 6 to 8 hours.

steps.title: Fill a tall glass with ice.
steps.content: Fill a tall glass with ice. If you are having more servings, take out more glasses. Plan on having 1 cup (240 milliliters) of iced tea per glass/serving.

steps.title: Take the tea bags out.
steps.content: Take the tea bags out. Give them a squeeze to release any excess liquid. If you used loose-leaf tea, don't worry about it just yet.

steps.title: Pour the chilled tea into the ice-filled glass.
steps.content: Pour the chilled tea into the ice-filled glass. If you used loose leaf tea, pour the tea through a strainer. If the tea leaves are finely ground, you may have to line the strainer with a coffee filter first.

steps.title: Sweeten the tea with honey, if desired, and serve.
steps.content: Sweeten the tea with honey, if desired, and serve. Be sure to stir the honey in well, if you are using it. If you made a lot of tea, store it in the fridge, and drink it within 3 to 5 days.

steps.title: Fill a mug with ½ cup (120 milliliters) of boiling water.
steps.content: Fill a mug with ½ cup (120 milliliters) of boiling water. You will be making a consecrated green tea lemonade first using a small amount of hot water. Don't worry, you will be adding more water to your tea later.

steps.title: Add 1 green tea bag into the water, and 2 tablespoons of sugar, if desired.
steps.content: Add 1 green tea bag into the water, and 2 tablespoons of sugar, if desired. If you'd like to use another type of sweetener, such as honey, skip the sugar; you will add the honey (or other sweetener) at the end. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Let the tea brew for 3 minutes, then take out the tea bag.
steps.content: Let the tea brew for 3 minutes, then take out the tea bag. Give the bag a squeeze to get out any excess liquid.

steps.title: Squeeze the juice out of 2 lemons, and add it to the tea.
steps.content: Squeeze the juice out of 2 lemons, and add it to the tea. If you'd like a little more tartness, add some lemon zest as well.

steps.title: Add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of cold water, and stir.
steps.content: Add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of cold water, and stir. This will help dilute the consecrated tea mixture, and make it less tart.

steps.title: Fill 1 to 2 glasses with ice.
steps.content: Fill 1 to 2 glasses with ice. How much ice you use is up to you, just make sure to leave enough room for the tea. This recipe is enough to make 1 large serving, or 2 smaller servings.

steps.title: Pour the green tea lemonade over the ice.
steps.content: Pour the green tea lemonade over the ice. The tea might still be a little warm, so don't worry if the ice melts a little. This is normal.

steps.title: Garnish, if desired, and serve.
steps.content: Garnish, if desired, and serve. You can serve your green tea lemonade as it is, or you can give it a pop of color. Popular green tea lemonade garnishes include mint leaves and lemon slices.
